reviewText: I have to confess, this game was just a ridiculous amount of fun. It felt like I was interacting in a cheesy spy novel, and it did a good job at it. Well, this is a third person stealth/action shooter. The first six to eight levels are more stealth oriented, but once the Russion Special Forces, (spetsnaz) are sent after you, you can pretty much kiss stealth goodbye. It's all shooting from there. It implements a system where you can collect gadgets lying around like rags, alarm clocks, plastic bottles, cans, chemicles, ect. and McGyver them into cheep tools for temporary use. For example, you can use a plastic bottle and rag at the end of your barrel for a cheep, disposible silencer. You can also make explosives, paralyzing chemicle agents, and other completely implausible but fun innovations. But not to worry. It is a very easy system to pick up with very little learning curve. The story is told through a series of comic book-like cutsceens between missions with corny, voice-acted Russian accents that, (in my opinion) adds a lot of charm to this game. I found myself drawn into it and empathizing with the characters. Also I loved the ending! This game is cheep, the controls are very good, the graphics are great for 2005, there is a quicksave system as opposed to a checkpoint saving system, and I ask you: what other game allows you to have a shootout inside of Lenin's tomb? This game has a lot of atmopshere and I highly recommend it. Honestly, if there is anything even remotely negative I can think to say about it, it is that the character moves kind of slow, and has a lot of wide open ground to cover. The sprint system only works for a few moments before your character gets tired and has to rest, so traveling while sprinting isn't too much faster in the long run than walking. Traveling from one side of a map to another can be a bit tedious. But this is a very minor complaint. This game is a definite winner.

reviewText:
Cold War is a 2005 made, parodic stealth action game. It is some kind of 3rd person view No One Lives Forever with hand-made gadgets which starring a journalist. It was really good first. I even planned to recommend it to you, but then, i got bored because of some problems and changed my mind. There are some summarized pros. and cons. below:

Pros	 + Story is interesting enough
+ Graphics are already outdated but it isn't ugly at all.
+ Some unique attractions like gadget crafting and X-Ray camera

Neutral	  No widescreen support. Control scheme a little bit weird and dull, but somewhat useful as well. Especially setting your walking speed with mouse wheel is a good idea. Music is OK but repetitive.

Cons - Stealth is a little bit dull. You can't do so much actions for best stealth results. Furthermore, at the last half of the game, say goodbye to stealth.
- Characters you control can't run. They pretend to do so but they seems like they are taking a stroll on the park. Any NPC runs well though.
- Aiming is bad. You can't change shoulders while aiming, so, time by time you can't see the target properly.
- You're playing on same locations over and over again.
- Planting gadgets like mines is deceptive. You have to stop the desired plant location first, then you have to highlight the gadget on the menu and left click to insta-plant.
- Background sound effects are annoying.
- A frustrating bug on Meltdown level ( spoiler:  When you try to stop meltdown in Chernobyl, you have to press two buttons and start the crane, right? Be careful, you have to use these buttons first or else... you can't use crane again. That means you need to restart the level.  )

After all, it worth for $1,25 but don't expect too much. Especially after the last half, quality of the game started to decrease in my humble opinion.

reviewText:
This game went on sale shortly after I finished Splinter Cell: Blacklist, it was on sale for $1.24 and when I saw the video I figured it would just be a low budget version of splinter cell and bought it because it was cheap and mostly for the lulz.

When I actually started playing the game I was pleasently surprised, as it turned out to be a lot more fun than I expected it to be.  My initial impression was mostly correct, this is essentially a low-budget version of splinter cell, but it is done well and if you enjoy stealth games you will probably like this.

The stealth is handled well, you have a visibility meter which shows how visible you are, and you have 4 movement speeds.  The slowest movement speed moves very slow(obv) but the enemies cannot hear you even if you are right behind them and as you increase in speed the enemies will be able to hear you from farther and farther away.  Movement is easily toggled and as you learn the correct distances to which an enemy can hear you, quickly toggling your speed becomes second nature.

You also are kind of a MacGyver, you find junk lying around(cans, plastic bottles, etc etc) and you can use this junk to craft al manner of items which make being stealthy easier and easier.  You unlock blueprints as they game goes on and once you unlock a print you can craft that item if you have the proper junk for it, is is all easily done and very intuititve.  The gadgets overall are very cool, you can make a slingshot and craft all manner of silent ammo for it, you can lay traps for enemies(both quiet and non-lethal to loud and boomy) and you can even create luring devices that will make your enemies plod right into your mine, provided you lay the trap in a dark place.  If you drop a mine in the light the enemies will see it and disarm it.

You also get an x-ray camera weapon which is beyond cool, it lets you see through walls and locate enemies before they can see you, and it even damages enemies through walls, although ammo is limited for it, it is very cool to be able to just blast enemies silently through a wall.

There are only 2 guns in the game, the pistol and an ak-47.  The vast majority of the game is stealth but there are a few run n gun sections, and luckily the gunplay handles well enough, although it is easy to bait the enemies into choke points and just blast them as they walk through.

The story is good, and rather lengthy, the game took me about 11-12 hours to complete and there are several twists and turns as the story progresses, it is entertaining and mostly well done.  There is also a save anywhere function which comes in handy, just be warned the game only auto saves at the start of levels so make sure you use the save system because the missions are generally pretty lengthy.

At a sale price of $1.24 this game was a steal, but even at the full price of 5 dollars you are getting your moneys worth.  If you enjoy stealth games like splinter cell you should pick this up, it is not as good or polished as that game, but it is a good time and well worth the low asking price.

reviewText:
If you consider that this game is eleven years old, it's not that bad. Sure, the animations are a bit wonky by today's standards and the highest available resolution is 1024x768, but the game runs at  smooth 60fps at my crappy lappot with stuff going on in the background.

This game wins my heart because of its setting and story. There is no other game in which you can stealth around Charnobyl, Kremlin AND Lubyanka. The AI is good as well, it is not perfect, but enemies will seek cover during firefights instead of standing in the middle of the room like bunch of idiots. They are not pansies too, they were trained in the Glorious Soviet Union, so they hurt. Really hurt.
The crafting system is good, I have no idea how Carter knows how to make a mine out of a can and three bullets, but it works in the game and is balanced, so I won't dig much. Maybe he was trained by the CIA after all... The 'camera' is a great gameplay tool as well.

There are of course some bad things. Apart from a bit dated visuals, which do not look bad if you ask me, the missions in which you control Comrade Grushkov are in my opinion the worst. Sure, I get it, he's a soldier so he does not sneak around, but in one of 'his' levels the enemies literally spawn in front of you. This also happens in one place towards the end of the campaign. All in all, the final few missions are IMO worse than the rest of the game, but your milage may wary.

All in all, for the asking price of 5EUR, and possibly even lower if you consider buying this on sale, it gives you a solid campaign with very unusual setting and challenging gameplay. I've finished the story in 7 hours on normal, but I've played the game at least twice few years ago, so I still remembered what to do and where to go.

TL;DR: If you're not terrified of dated visuals and have few bucks lying around, give it a try.
